keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris suffered a major heist in October 2025, during which nine historically significant jewels were stolen from the Apollo Gallery, including a sapphire diadem, emerald necklace, and multiple pieces linked to Empress Eugénie.
The heist, which lasted only seven minutes, targeted high-security display cases and involved four thieves who fled on motorcycles.
One of the most valuable items, Empress Eugénie’s crown, was recovered near the scene, though damaged during the theft.
The jewelry has deep historical and cultural significance, linking to Napoleon, Marie-Louise, and key figures in French royal history.
The items were not only valuable in monetary terms but also represent national heritage and identity, making the theft a 'national disaster'.
Art expert Arthur Brand warned that the thieves may have dismantled the stolen pieces to melt down gold and silver, highlighting the threat to cultural preservation.
The recovery of the crown demonstrates that some items were not fully lost, though the full recovery of all stolen items remains uncertain.
The stolen jewelry includes pieces with documented provenance, such as the emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise and the sapphire diadem once belonging to queens of the Orléans family.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is central to several stolen and recovered items, including the reliquary brooch, the pearl diadem, and the bow brooch, making her a key historical figure in the context of the heist.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, a major theft occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris, where four thieves stole nine historically significant jewels from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes. Among the items stolen were a sapphire diadem and emerald necklace linked to Napoleon and Marie-Louise, and several pieces belonging to Empress Eugénie, including a reliquary brooch and a pearl diadem. The heist was described by experts as a 'national disaster' due to the cultural and historical value of the items. One of the most valuable items, Eugénie’s crown, was partially damaged during the break-in but was later recovered near the scene. Art recovery expert Arthur Brand warned that the thieves may have dismantled the stolen pieces to melt down gold and silver, posing a serious threat to cultural preservation. The items have deep historical roots, with provenance tracing back to 18th and 19th century French royalty and artisans. Though some items were recovered, the full extent of the loss and the fate of the stolen pieces remain uncertain, highlighting a significant moment in the global preservation of cultural heritage.
title: Historic jewels stolen in ‘national disaster’ for France: What we know about missing Louvre treasures
